dt.t: the … Loyalists found {wi}harbor{/wi} in the same areas

dt: {bc}a part of a body of water protected and deep enough to furnish anchorage

et: Middle English {it}herberwe, herberowe, herbour, harborow{/it} "quarters, lodgings, field camp of an army, shelter for a traveler," going back to Old English {it}herebeorg{/it} "shelter, lodgings," going back to Germanic {it}*haribergō-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}herberge{/it} "lodging, inn," Old Saxon {it}heriberga{/it} "army camp," Old High German {it}heriberga, herberga{/it} "army camp, lodging for a traveler, accommodations," Old Norse {it}herbergi{/it} "inn, room"), from {it}*harja-{/it} "body of armed men" + {it}*-bergō-{/it} "shelter, protection," noun derivative from the base of {it}*bergan-{/it} "to keep safe" (whence Old English {it}beorgan{/it} [strong verb class III] "to protect, defend, preserve," Old Saxon {it}gibergan{/it} "to protect," Old High German {it}bergan{/it} "to save, preserve, conceal," Old Norse {it}bjarga{/it} "to save," Gothic {it}bairgan{/it} "to keep, preserve"), going back to dialectal Indo-European {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}erg{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} whence also Old Church Slavic {it}nebrěgǫ, nebrěšti{/it} "to disregard, neglect," Czech {it}brh{/it} "hayrick, cave, hut" (from {it}*bĭrgŭ{/it}), Czech {it}brah{/it} "hayrick," Polish {it}bróg{/it} "hayrick, barn for hay" (from {it}*borgŭ{/it}), Lithuanian {it}bìrginti{/it} "to be sparing, not spend much," Old Irish {it}commairce{/it} "protection, refuge" (from {it}*ḱom-b{sup}h{/sup}org{sup}h{/sup}-i̯e-{/it}) {ma}{mat|harry|}{/ma}

Middle English forms such as {it}herboru{/it} and {it}harborow{/it} appear to show assimilation of the second element of the compound to variants of {it}burgh{/it} "town, fortified dwelling" (see {et_link|borough|borough}). — Germanic {it}*bergan-{/it} has been associated with {it}*berga-{/it} "hill, mountain" (see {et_link|barrow:1|barrow:1}), on the assumption that a high place would be a place of refuge, though the Indo-European base underlying {it}*berga-{/it} is {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}erǵ{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} not {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}erg{sup}h{/sup}-.{/it} An etymon {it}b{sup}h{/sup}erǵ{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} however, would rule out the clearly related Balto-Slavic forms, which do not have a palatovelar stop. The link could only be maintained if the Balto-Slavic base was borrowed from Germanic, but the full display of ablaut and diversification of meaning in Slavic make borrowing unlikely.
shortdef: a place of security and comfort : refuge
a part of a body of water protected and deep enough to furnish anchorage; especially : one with port facilities

dt: {bc}to be the home or habitat of

dt.t: a town that {wi}harbors{/wi} several textile factories

dt: {bc}to hold especially persistently in the mind {bc}{sx|cherish||}
{bc}to take shelter in or as if in a harbor

et: Middle English {it}herberwen, herborewen{/it} "to lodge, give shelter to," going back to Old English {it}herebeorgian,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*haribergōjan-{/it} (whence also Middle Dutch {it}herbergen{/it} "to provide shelter for," Old High German {it}heribergōn{/it} "to set up quarters for an army, stay as a guest," Old Norse {it}herbergja{/it} "to shelter [a person], lodge"), derivative of {it}*haribergō-{/it} "shelter for an armed force" {ma}{mat|harbor:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to give shelter or refuge to
to be the home or habitat of; broadly : contain
to hold especially persistently in the mind : cherish

dt: {bc}a surprise attack often with devastating effect

et: {it}Pearl Harbor{/it}, Oahu, Hawaii, American naval station attacked without warning by the Japanese on December 7, 1941
shortdef: a surprise attack often with devastating effect
